I'm sticking with my call for Macri to win, but the statement by Pope Francis today makes me slightly less confident. Pope's remarks from link below:
“You already know what I think,” he first said and then added: “Vote with conscience.”
Given his well known criticism of unhindered capitalism, this statement seems to be an implied endorsement of Scioli. The Argentinian Pope's potential to influence voters in in the election should not be underestimated in my opinion.

Reuters (Fri Nov 13, 2015), "An opinion poll this week by consultancy group Management & Fit showed Macri with the support of 51.8 percent of voters and Scioli trailing on 43.6 percent."  http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/13/argentina-election-macri-idUSL8N13659F20151113

Today is the last day before the runoff election that polls are allowed to published, according to Argentine law. An average of polls taken after the first-round election strongly suggests a Macri victory. See http://buenosairesherald.com/article/202952/polls-put-macri-ahead
"Polls put Macri ahead
Nine out of 10 surveys point to a Let’s Change victory
Eight days out from the presidential runoff, an aggregate of polls suggests that Let’s Change presidential candidate Mauricio Macri will be able to convert his strong second-place finish into a victory against rival Daniel Scioli of the Victory Front (FpV) in the November 22 runoff. Scioli edged Macri in the general elections last month by about three percentage points but polls on taken since the election consistently placed the Let’s Change candidate with a lead of between two and 11 points. La Borra, a blog run by political scientists who aggregates polls, has placed the average margin held by Macri over Scioli to be around six percentage points. The average is drawn from 10 polls, all of which were carried out after the October 25 general election. Nine out of those 10 indicated that Macri is in pole position to replace President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner at the Pink House." On the other hand, there is still a lot of uncertainty in the polling: See the same article: http://buenosairesherald.com/article/202952/polls-put-macri-ahead
"Ahead of the general elections, the vast majority of publicly-available surveys suggested that Scioli was on the cusp of the 10-point margin required to win the presidency outright. Those predictions proved to be totally off base. The only pollster to have come close to the final was result was the consultancy Elypsis, which correctly predicted a runoff. Elypsis published results only days after the election which gave Macri a 10-point lead over Scioli. One of the reasons given by analysts is that the surveys were unable to account for the increased turnout between the primaries and the runoff. The runoff will also pose new kinds of problems for the pollsters as the more than five million voters who voted for defeated presidential candidates have the option of casting a blank vote — determining how exactly voters realign their support in the unique circumstances of a runoff will add a layer of complexity." And see: http://en.mercopress.com/2015/11/14/argentine-analyst-says-8-decide-their-vote-on-election-day
"“I believe there is a majority of Massa voters who will support Macri. But one thing are the Massa votes in Cordoba and another those in La Matanza, a Buenos Aires province district, who really believe Scioli is the only one capable or reining the province, and not some other hopeful”. Likewise Giacobbe said it was in “Scioli's interest that less voters turn out on 22 November when the runoff, while for Macri the opposite is best, the more voters the better so he can overtake the small difference he experienced in October”. But above all “we must remember that 70% of voters act on a rather reasonable logic, while for 30% it's like choosing between Frankenstein and the wolf man, since they do not like or feel comfortable with any of the two candidates”. Giacobbe also recalled that despite what opinion polls might be indicating, experience shows that in runoffs the difference is normally just a few percentage points, no matter the candidates," Other sources: http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/11/14/uk-argentina-election-idUKKCN0T310L20151114
"The poll, conducted by Management & Fit and published in newspaper Clarin, gave Macri about an 8 percentage point advantage over ruling party candidate Daniel Scioli, the governor of Buenos Aires province, who has been endorsed by Fernandez. In the survey Macri got a voter intention rating of 52 percent versus 43.7 percent for Scioli, factoring in each candidate's projected share of undecided voters. The poll of 2,400 voters taken last week had a margin of error of plus of minus 3 percent. The poll results were virtually unchanged from a Management & Fit survey released a week earlier."
Too close to call, Mauricio Macri polled ahed f Daniel Scioli but Sergio Massa holds the key, not yet revealed.

I'm putting a 100% on Macri (just to mitigate my having 100% on Scioli for most of this question's existence). I've had some terrible luck recently on election questions (the Polish and Turkish elections, specifically), so I'm being a little more cautious with this one, especially because there's data indicating that Macri is now the... front-runner? Nov 8th -- "Macri pulls ahead in Argentina presidential race, poll shows": http://news.yahoo.com/opposition-candidate-macri-leads-argentina-presidential-race-poll-151604522--sector.html The Management & Fit survey put Macri eight points ahead with the backing of 51.8 percent of voters, including a projected share of undecided votes. His rival, Daniel Scioli, had 43.6 percent support. ... However, more than one in 10 of Argentina's 32 million voters are still undecided, leaving the presidential race open. Macri's lead narrows to six points with 46.3 percent of support when undecided votes are excluded from the candidates' count. ~~~~ Comment: So, it looks like it's going to be close, but even though my inkling (HA! Inkles, anyone?) is that Scioli will still pull it out, the data point to a Macri win (at this point) and so I've gotta sway my forecast to mitigate for that possibility.

Massa has chosen not to endorse either of the two candidates, as he may easily be the coalition partner of either Macri or Scioli depending on the runoff  results.  Base aleignment has Scioli and Massa as Peronists and Macri the outsider. It is as valid to say that the two Peronist parties scored almost 60% in the first round, ignoring the pro-business candidate, as to make the same statement combining the Macri/Scioli vote against Scioli.  Election may show how much the electorate has changed.  Forecast stays with Macri to balance out earlier forecasts.

http://en.mercopress.com/2015/11/07/argentina-massa-tells-ft-he-has-been-given-the-task-of-controlling-government Massa says he's not supporting either of the two other lads. This probably helps Macri slightly more than Scioli, since it cuts more peronistas loose to vote against Cristina's anointed. There is an excellent chance I am wrong about this, so I am cravenly not changing my numbers just now.

Run off is between Scioli (37%) and Macri (34%) after a first-round election with an 81% (!) turnout. Massa received 21%. Massa has a history of affiliation with Scioli's party and coalition, splitting from them only recently over what seem to be personality issues with Kirchner. Policy stances seem to be more left than right and if Massa's supporters break the same way then the advantage is to Scioli in the runoff. The three candidates who split the remaining 7% or so of the vote all dress left, so likewise advantage Scioli. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_2015

Outgoing president Cristina Fernandez has suggested people vote for the candidate most likely to continue her programs (Scioli) and Massa has not endorsed either but has said he does not want Macri to win.
the guy polling second has so much incentive and a little more flexibility, which the front runner freezes hoping that nothing changes, afraid to smile too broadly

http://en.mercopress.com/tags/argentina-general-elections-2015 A good source on this, and generally consistent with what the Spanish-language press are saying.  At any rate this source is better than my friends in Argentina, too many of whom--apparently seeking to emulate Amurricans--are proud of themselves for not knowing anything about their country's politics or government.  My record in guessing other people's political outcomes would have to get a lot better to be promoted to Terrible, but one must try.

After listening to this weeks Economist I am radicly changing my forecast. Macri may lack "inspiration" but is a good "team builder" and "consensus seeker" and his 34.9% share of the vote in the first round is just shy of Sciolis 36.9, who had been expected to have done much better. Marci now has a good chance of winning and his desires for strong instutions and free markets will please many. The stock market and peso are up. A survey has shown that 40% of people want a radical overhall. Sciolis party lost a major governorship. So why can win the votes of Massa? As he is anti-corruption it is likely to me Macri. As this is reflecting the desire already shown in Europe, and before that in North Africa and before that in Eastern Europe for a different/better government I am moving from 50:50 to 100% Macri. I will adjust if external events or spanners get thrown in the works.

First round of voting over. Analyze the results. Macri vote way over polls estimate. Virtual tie with Scioli.
As I predicted there was a surge of anti-Kirchner voting and no reason to believe that Scioli will pick up the majority of Massa support which is  twice more likely given Massa plaform and supporters. No reason to believe that Macri cannot and will not pick up that vote. No reason to believe anti-KIrchner sentiment reversing, it is surging even stronger See election results.
See only poll I could locate after first round  According to the González & Valladares poll, done on Monday and Tuesday { one week ago}, Macri figures with a vote intention of 45.6% against 41.5% for Scioli, with an additional 4,5% who anticipate a blank vote and 8.8% of interviews undecided. linkhttp://en.mercopress.com/2015/10/29/macri-ahead-of-scioli-with-8.8-still-undecided-shows-first-poll-following-sunday-s-vote

Scioli's popularity is declining in latest polls in spite of backing from outgoing president Cristina Kirchner. He was leading in tracking polls by 10 percent going into the presidential voting last week but just squeaked by coming in in front of  Buenos Aires mayor Mauricio Macri and his "We Change" faction that leans away from statist economy favoried  by the Kirchnerismo faction of Peronism, with 36.5% to Macri's 34.2%.  As a result there will be a second round runoff in the presidential election for the first time in post-junta "Argentine democracy." All because Scioli, the governor of Buenos Aires province could not beat Macri decisively. There is a lot of backroom dealing and smoke and mirrors media and social media action going on for the Massa votes (an anti-Kirchnerismo grouping in Peronism) which may shift to Macri. If this happens it could end Kirchnerismo's grip on the Peronist party.  Here is a link to latest polling data, indicating that Macri is pulling out in front of Scioli with 8 percent undecided.Link is here  http://en.mercopress.com/2015/10/29/macri-ahead-of-scioli-with-8.8-still-undecided-shows-first-poll-following-sunday-s-vote

Some considerations:
1.  Scioli’s lackluster results versus Peronists (Scioli, Massa, and Saá) winning 60% of the vote.
2.  How loyal Peronists are to the cause.
3.  Kirchner, a divisive figure, only giving Scioli luke-warm endorsements.  Does she think he is beatable in four years?  
4.  Massa, in a bid to preserve his political future, giving only a “wink” to Macri, not an endorsement.

http://en.mercopress.com/2015/10/29/macri-ahead-of-scioli-with-8.8-still-undecided-shows-first-poll-following-sunday-s-vote Macri leads first election poll - Macri@45.6%, Scioli@41.5%.   Remainder are blank ballots or undecided.

Taking a neutral position until there are more polls to judge by.
Following jkbrick, outstanding research, thank you. I'm tilting further toward Macri than him to compensate for my earlier forecasts in favor of Scioli.

After the first go leaving just the two candidates. Macro with 34% and Scioli with 36 it could be a close thing but with the next biggest number of votes having gone to Massa I think it likely that unless an alliance is formed the majority of his supporters will vote for the other PJ candidate. Also with Massas' previous links with the kirchner family it's a safe bet that his voters will make the most obvious switch.  This combined with the likely scare tactics used by his party leading up to the election will cause the public to choose what appears to be the most economically risk averse option.

Scioli seems to have done much worse in the primary election than expected; he got 37% of the vote against Macri's 35%.  The key seems to be who third-place candidate Massa will support.  Scioli's slight lead in the first round would seem to give him a slight advantage, but Massa seems to be more likely to support Massa.  I am giving equal odds to both.

There is still uncertainty about alliances among parties and their platforms and how it will affect the run-off in November.   Some indicators suggest closer alignment between Macri & Massa.  Massa is currently in the progress of  formulating a policy blueprint that could reflect the business interests in Macri's platform indicating a "tacit wink."

The majority of voters that voted for Massa and the others openly reject the current government's political and economic model; short story Macri can grow substantially, Scioli's potential is limited.

If the AP report is true, it's going to be a bumpy ride. "The third-place finisher in Argentina's presidential election hinted Tuesday that he will support opposition candidate Mauricio Macri in the runoff vote."

http://www.foxnews.com/world/2015/10/27/no-3-in-argentina-first-round-presidential-election-hints-at-backing-opposition/

Several of the also-rans are described as Peronists like Scioli, but that's a big tent, and the label has never precluded its adherents from making deals with others in the interest of winning.  Macri can win if Massa signs on with him, but he'd have to offer a pretty sweet deal.  Otherwise it's probably Scioli in a squeaker.
This weeks Economist suggests this to me, but this is just my first thought on this. Adapted for Cora comment.

Massa with 21%  has endorsed Macri with 34%.
I'm going to over-correct and go higher with Macri to compensate for previously lower forecasts for him.

We have to watch what happens next to be able to distinguish more into the future.
This will be a close upset

"Eying the possibility of an alliance between Mr. Macri and Mr. Massa, political analysts were examining how many of Mr. Massa’s supporters could help swing the vote. Some estimate that about a third of Mr. Massa’s support came from dissident Peronists who could actually swing back to Mr. Scioli, potentially handing him a victory. “That greatly limits Massa’s margin for maneuver,” said Sergio Berensztein, an Argentine political analyst. Still, he said Mr. Macri would have already contemplated how to court this 30 percent, pointing to a statue of Juan Domingo Perón, the founder of Peronism, that Mr. Macri recently unveiled. “That’s why he inaugurated the statue,” Mr. Berensztein said."

Daniel Scioli, is a former vice president who has served as governor of Buenos Aires Province since 2007 and was endorsed by Cristina Kirchner (present President). His main competitors are Sergio Massa, a centrist who leads a party called the Renewal Front, and Mauricio Macri, the leader of the center-right Republican Proposal. Mr. Macri is the mayor of Buenos Aires and appeals to voters who believe Mrs. Kirchner’s Imperial economic policies have isolated the country.  Argentinians are sick and tired of Cristina and her party.

This isolated Argentina financially and they are having serious economical impact in their economy.

Currently governor of Buenos Aires province, Scioli is the hand picked successor of president Cristina Kirchner, who cannot succeed herself by law. He was also endorsed by former president Lula of Brazil who recently spent several days in Argentina strategizing with Cristina. Scioli represents the moderate faction of the left wing Kirchnerismo faction within Peronism. Argentina uses an antiquated paper ballot system, which could raise some issues.

The primary, polls and betting odds all point to Scioli.  But if he misses the threshold to win it in October, things could change come November.

Good Post Primary analysis: http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/monkey-cage/wp/2015/08/20/heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-argentinas-2015-federal-elections/ Scioli favored, Massa has chance and Macri unlikely. Main factor Scoli does not need many more votes, and Kirchner's support and ability to make deals should make the difference. Analysis of the Argentine political parties:
 The Peronist Movement has two wings: the Pro Kirchner wing (Scioli) and the Anti Kirchner wing (Massa). Both wings fundamentally agree on the basic Peronist concepts: support of the working class and the poor.  Together they gained 60% of the primary vote.  In a second round vote these are the most likely candidates to win. The Cambios Alliance (Macri): Pro business candidate supports free markets and US tendencies.  Gained 30% of primary vote, but has very little upside. Scioli seems like the only candidate that can win outright in the first round of voting in October. That is a positive. Kirchner supports Scioli, although he is not seen as at loyalist.  By selecting Carlos Zannini, close confidant of Kirchner, as his VP candidate, he may have both the pro and some anti Kerchner vote in a second round.  Scioli reportedly has opportunity to cut deals for the few remaining votes to win in the first round. Other outcomes: mostly based on an alliance between Cambios and United for a New Alternative (UNA , Massa).  Assuming it is unlikely that Cambios can win on it's own, the Anti-Kirchner  (Massa) wing should have the most influence.  Combined this combination drew almost 51% in the primary vote.  Macri couldhe presidency as a figurehead, as Cambios will not have the votes in Parliament to exercise much power.  More likely Massa would be able to supply more Parliamentary support, if this were to be a coalition.

Kirchner government seems to have created a sense of dependency upon it which economic issues probably only compound. A more positive experience might give more confidence to vote for the unknown. But if not winning in first round, run-off could be tight as opposition votes coalesce.

The biggest question left to answer is how Massa's vote will split, no matter whether it occurs during the general election or the runoff. The limited information available indicates that Massa's vote will be absorbed most by the Scioli camp, though this is far from assured.
Moreso, the 8 to 10 percentage points by which Scioli leads over Macri is consistent and significant. Using this as the best predictor available, the likelihood weighs heavily for Scioli's election.

during the primaries Daniel Scioli, the nominee of the governing party, took more than 38 percent of the vote, besting the alliance of his main rival, Mauricio Macri.

This Washington Post article seems pretty useful: https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/monkey-cage/wp/2015/08/20/heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-argentinas-2015-federal-elections/  From that - looks like the primary in early August was a better indicator than polls are likely to be.  Scioli took 38.4% of the vote, only candidate tabulated for his party.  Macri had 24.3%, his party took 30.1% overall, but votes from the two other candidates may not go to Macri in the general election.  Massa had 14.2% of the vote.  To win, a candidate needs 45% of the vote or 40% of the vote and a 10% margin over the closest rival.  Scioli is not that far off of the second set of conditions.  WP article thinks his best bet is to make deals with the other candidates/politicians to take votes that might have gone to Massa.  Two possibilities were mentioned:  governor-elect Juan Schiaretti in Cordoba (successor to De la Sota, second place candidate in Massa's party), and Rodriquez Saa, from another party.  So -> look for news of deals that will chip away Massa's votes to Scioli.  Or, lack of news of deals.   Management and Fit's poll in late August showed Scioli up a bit more at 39.3% and Macri at 31.2.   Other info, Daniel Marcelino has an interesting post up on the Argentine election, and looks in more depth at house effects between the various polling organizations: http://danielmarcelino.com/argentine-general-election-2015/

" "Scioli attracted the most votes in primaries to choose presidential candidates in August."  According to a Management & Fit poll taken late last month:
36.7% for Scioli, governor of Buenos Aires Province
29.2% for Mauricio Macri, Buenos Aires city Mayor

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/11/world/americas/primaries-in-argentina-point-to-a-close-presidential-race.html?_r=0   (edited copy/paste) "An all-party presidential primary, billed as a measure of the nation’s desire for change, proved close enough to cast doubt on who would prevail in general elections." . . .  " . . .  Scioli took more than 38% percent of the vote. . . .  But the eight-point margin of victory was not sufficient to gauge confidently how voters will approach the general election on Oct. 25.  . .. .  With 98 percent of the votes counted on Monday, the primary results were seen as inconclusive, complicated by uncertainty over how many votes might drift away from a third political bloc, led by Sergio Massa, which got 21 percent of Sunday’s tally." "Argentina switched to an open primary system in 2011. Unlike the United States, primary elections in Argentina are mandatory for all voters, not just those from a specific party. The candidate from each party or alliance that gets the most votes will run in October’s general election." "Mr. Scioli is “in a very good position and remains favored to win,”. . . . ” "A sticking point for Mr. Scioli may be Buenos Aires Province, home to more than a third of voters. His party’s nominee for governor there, Aníbal Fernández, is Mrs. Kirchner’s cabinet chief and has been tainted by accusations of links to drug trafficking. Though Mr. Fernández denies malfeasance, the issue and his closeness to Mrs. Kirchner are barriers to attracting swing voters, said Carlos Germano, an Argentine political analyst." ". . .that increases the probability of a runoff in which Mr. Macri, whose candidate for governor performed well Sunday in a parallel primary, could unite the opposition and overcome Mr. Scioli."

There should be a runoff election. We'll get some good data from the first-round election. For now, I'll just rely on the polls. Daniel Scioli has increased his lead in the August Management & Fit poll. Cristina Kirchner's approval rating has also been increasing and Scioli is running on a platform on continuity with the Kirchner administration. Awaiting the September poll. My 1% probability for "someone else" takes into account a black swan event (e.g., the death + replacement of a candidate as happened in the recent Brazilian presidential election).
